thread.title_full: Coming Attractions in San Antonio - San Antonio Express-News

author: mysanantonio.com
title: Coming Attractions in San Antonio -
text:
Photo: Associated Press Image 1 of / 1 1 Michael Fassbender stars as Steve Jobs. Michael Fassbender stars as Steve Jobs. Photo: Associated Press Coming Attractions in San Antonio 1 / 1 Back to Gallery Oct. 23
Jem and the Holograms: The ’80s animated TV series is reborn, with Aubrey Peeples (“Nashville”) starring as Jem, a small-town girl who’s the lead singer of an aspiring young band that includes her three sisters. Molly Ringwald is Jem’s aunt and mother figure.
The Last Witch Hunter: Humanity is threatened by a horrifying league of witches, led by the resurrected, revenge-minded Queen Witch. Only gravelly-voiced Vin Diesel can save them.
Paranormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension: Found-footage franchise’s sixth and reportedly final installment “will have answers to every question you have about the mythology of the series,” producer Jason Blum promised in an interview with wegotthiscovered.com. The latest chapter involves a game developer trying to protect his daughter from supernatural forces in their new home.
Rock the Kasbah: Call this “Afghan Idol”? Bill Murray is an over-the-hill rock manager on a USO tour of Afghanistan who discovers a girl with an amazing voice and helps her compete in “Afghan Star,” an “American Idol” knockoff. Unfortunately, the Clash’s “Rock the Casbah” is not in the trailer (which instead features Free’s “All Right Now”) or on the soundtrack. Say it ain’t so…
Steve Jobs : The late Apple founder’s turbulent life gets its second big-screen treatment, which appears to be light years ahead of the critically lambasted “Jobs” (2013) starring Ashton Kutcher . Oscar-winner Michael Fassbender has the title role in this behind-the-scenes bio that looks into three product launches, from 1984 (the Apple II) to 1998 (the iMac). Already a film-festival favorite, “Steve Jobs” boasts a writing and directing team with impeccable credentials Written by Aaron Sorkin (”The West Wing,” “The Social Network,” “Moneyball”) and directed by Danny Boyle (“Trainspotting,” “Slumdog Millionaire”).
